11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-013-9697-5969710.1007/s11243-013-9697-5ArticleHydrothermal syntheses, crystal structures and fluorescent properties of five transition metal–organic hybrids incorporating an unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylate ligandZhangZhong1aHuKun1ShiYun-jia1QinJin-man1ChenZi-lu1LiangFu-pei1grid.459584.10000000121960260Key Laboratory for the Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources (Ministry of Education of China), School of Chemistry & Chemical EngineeringGuangxi Normal University541004GuilinPeople’s Republic of China+86-773-5854878+86-773-5832294zhangzhong@mailbox.gxnu.edu.cn2912013420133833273341112013812201210120132912013© Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 20132013Abstract

The hydrothermal reactions of nitrate or chloride salts of Co(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Ag(I) with an unsymmetrical benzotriazole derivative 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-propionic acid (Hbtap) afforded five new metal–organic coordination polymers with formula of [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3), [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) and {[Ag(btap)]·H2O}n (5), which were characterized by X-ray diffraction and spectroscopic methods. The anionic btap− ligands in these complexes assume the same anti conformation, but show different coordination behaviors toward transition metal ions. Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and reveal infinite one-dimensional (1D) looped-chain structures constructed by hexacoordinated metal centers and 2-connected btap− bridges. Complex 4 features 1D zigzag polymeric arrays, which are interlinked with each other resulting in a chiral three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework. In complex 5, the 3-connected ligands join Ag(I) atoms into a 1D ribbon motif. The photoluminescence spectra of three d10 metal complexes 2, 3 and 4 were measured at room temperature. The emission peaks of these complexes resemble that of the free ligand and can be ascribed to the intraligand π–π* transitions.

Introduction

Studies on the modular assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have provided researchers in crystal engineering and materials science with a promising tool to construct extended coordination polymers with predicted structures and functionalities [1–3]. In the recent years, a great number of hybrid coordination frameworks with novel structures have been obtained by employing the modular synthesis strategy, and many of them offer a wide range of applications such as gas storage and separation, optical and chemical sensing, magnetic materials, and so on [4–7]. Even so, more experimental research will be needed to give us detailed information about the general principles of the design and synthesis of MOFs.

In fact, the judicious selection of organic connectors with appropriate flexibility, suitable arrangement of the donor groups as well as specific coordination requirements may be regarded as a key ingredient in determining the dimensionality, network topology, porosity and physical–chemical properties of the metal–organic coordination networks [8–11]. For this reason, many multidentate O-containing and N-containing bridging ligands have been used as effective building blocks in the construction of the metal–organic frameworks with desired structures and properties [12–14]. Among them, azole heterocycles have proved to be versatile synthons for developing a new type of porous material termed as metal-azolate frameworks (MAFs) [15–18]. As a further investigation, the introduction of the carboxylic acid substituents on the azole rings will afford a class of bifunctional connectors with strong coordination affinity, multiple coordination modes and variable geometric conformations. In the past few years, this sub-field has drawn much attention from many research groups, and some studies on the optical properties of the metal–organic hybrids derived from these ligands have been reported [19–24]. In this paper, grafting of the flexible propionic acid pendant arm onto a benzotriazole ring gives rise to a heterocyclic carboxylic acid derivative Hbtap as bridging ligand. The coordination capability of the ligand toward some transition metal ions was investigated systematically for the first time (Scheme 1), and four low-dimensional coordination polymers formulated as [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3) and {[Ag(btap)]·H2O}n (5), along with a 3D chiral framework [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) were produced. The thermal behaviors and photoluminescence emission properties of some selected complexes were explored.

Experimental sectionMaterials and physical measurements

The ligand Hbtap was prepared following a published procedure [25]. All other starting materials were purchased from Merck in analytical grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was carried out using an Elementar Vario Micro Cube elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were collected at 500 MHz on a Bruker Avance AV500 instrument, (CD3)2SO and TMS were used as solvent and internal standard, respectively. IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the 4,000–400 cm−1 spectral region. Thermogravimetric analysis was obtained using a Setaram Labsys Evo TG–DTA/DSC instrument at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The fluorescence spectra were performed on a Horiba Jobin–Yvon FL3-P-TCSPC fluorescence spectrometer in the solid state at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements (PXRD) for poly-crystalline samples of complexes 1–5 were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 V diffractometer equipped with Cu–Ka radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) over the 2θ range from 5° to 60°.

Synthesis of [Co(btap)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Hbtap (0.076 g, 0.40 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.058 g, 0.20 mmol) and 12 ml distilled water was sealed in a 25-ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 120 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the mixture was slowly cooled to ambient temperature over 24 h for crystallization. The pink block crystals of 1 were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water for several times and dried in air. Yield 0.040 g (42 % based on Co). Anal. Crystal structure determination

The diffraction data for complexes 1–5 were collected on an Agilent SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL program package [26]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were found in the difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with the O–H bond distances restrained to 0.85 Å, all other hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined as riding models. Details of crystal data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1–5 are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) for complexes 1–5 are summarized in Table S1. Hydrogen bond distances (Å) and angles (°) for complex 1–5 are listed in Table S2.

Results and discussionSynthesis and IR spectra

The ligand Hbtap was synthesized by the Michael addition of 1,2,3-benzotriazole to acrylic acid in 1:1 molar ratio, whose 1H NMR spectrum is given in Fig. S1. Complexes 1–5 were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions, and the stoichiometry of the corresponding complexes is independent of the metal to ligand ratio employed (1:1; 1:2; 1:3). However, the yields of products from different experimental runs are quite different. As shown in Fig. S2, the IR spectra of all the complexes show characteristic νas and νs stretching bands of COO− groups in the wavenumber ranges of 1,582–1,564 cm−1 and 1,417–1,404 cm−1, respectively, accompanied by the absence of the C=O stretching band of the carboxyl group, confirming that the ligands present in these solid complexes are fully deprotonated.

Description of the crystal structures

Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and isomorphous, which exhibit the same 1D infinite looped-chain structure. Thus, we only select complex 1 as a representative to describe their crystal structures. Complex 1 belongs to monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and the local coordination environment of the central Co(II) atom is depicted in Fig. 1. As can be seen, the Co(II) atom lies on the crystallographic inversion center, and it has an N2O4 donor set defined by two triazole N atoms (N3 and N3A) from two anionic btap− ligands, two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1A) from another two btap− ligands and two O atoms (O3 and O3A) provided by two water ligands. The cis bond angles at the central Co(II) atom fall in the range of 87.30(8)°–92.70(8)°, very close to the ideal value of 90°, which reveal that the geometry around Co(II) is slightly distorted from regular octahedral. The Co–O bond length of 2.0610(18) Å and Co–N bond length of 2.0997(18) Å are all comparable to the values found for the analogous Co(II) complexes [27, 28]. In 1, each btap− serves as a bidentate linker to connect two Co(II) atoms by using its triazole group and carboxylate substituent (mode a in Scheme 1), while one Co(II) atom is surrounded by four btap− ligands, giving rise to a 1D looped-chain composed of vertex-sharing 16-membered cyclic [Co2(btap)2] subunits (Fig. 2). Within the bimetallic ring, two symmetry-related anionic ligands bridge two metal centers in a head-to-tail fashion and each of them adopts an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1–C7–C8A–C9A being −161.7(2)°. The shortest Co…Co separation through the flexible bifunctional ligand is 8.715 Å, much longer than that observed in the Co–btae− (btae− = 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-acetate) complex [27].

The neighboring 1D metal–organic hybrid chains are arranged in an antiparallel fashion along the bc plane, and the O–H…O hydrogen bond interactions between water ligands and carboxylate groups assemble these 1D chains into a 2D hydrogen bonding network (Fig. S3). Viewed from the crystallographic b axis, hydrophobic aromatic rings are evenly distributed on the two sides of the 2D layer, which can facilitate the π–π stacking between the aromatic rings from adjacent layers to extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular net (Fig. S4). The interplanar distance between parallel benzotriazole rings is 3.357 Å, and the centriod–centriod separation is 4.019 Å.

If HgCl2 was used as a metal source in place of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, a neutral chiral 3D metal–organic framework 4 including the coordinated Cl− ligands was generated. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the central Hg(II) atom is located in a severely distorted six-coordinated NO4Cl geometry, surrounded by a triazole N atom (N3A) of one btap− ligand, four carboxylate O atoms (O1, O2, O1B and O2C) from another three btap− ligands and a chloride ligand. The two shortest bonds around the Hg(II) atoms are to the triazole N atom and Cl− ion with the bond lengths of 2.173(7) and 2.316(2) Å, respectively. The Hg–O bond lengths change from 2.525(7) to 2.721(7) Å. These values are expected for the bonds between the chelating-bridging carboxylate and Hg(II) atoms [29]. With its μ3 chelating-bridging carboxylate group and triazole N3 atom, each btap− ligand acts as a 4-connected organic node linked with four Hg(II) atoms (mode b in Scheme 1). At first, the flexible btap− linkers join the adjacent Hg(II) atoms into a 1D zigzag chain along the b axis. The Hg…Hg separation across btap− is 10.455 Å. The ligands within the chain assume the anti conformation, having the torsion angle N1–C7–C8–C9 close to 180°. Furthermore, the 1D zigzag chains are linked with each other through the bridging action of the carboxylate O1 and O2 atoms between Hg(II) atoms coming from different 1D chains, to yield a uninodal 4-connected 3D polymeric network with a (42.63.8) topology (Fig. 4). The π–π stacking interactions between aromatic rings of adjacent chains provide additional stabilization to the 3D architecture.

Complex 5 also crystallizes in a monoclinic P2(1)/c space group, yet it shows some different structural characteristics with respect to complexes 1, 2 and 3. Two chelating carboxylate O atoms (O1B and O2B) and two triazole N atoms (N3 and N2A) from three distinct btap− ligands occupy the coordination sites around the Ag(I) atom to give a twisted tetrahedral environment, where the O–Ag–N bond angles deviate from the ideal value of 109.47° (Fig. 5). The Ag–N and Ag–O bond distances vary from 2.227(2) to 2.524(2) Å and fall into the normal range for such coordination species [23]. The anionic ligands firstly bridge Ag(I) atoms through the carboxylate groups and triazole N3 atoms into a 1D linear chain running along the a axis. After that, two neighboring antiparallel chains are paired via Ag1–N2 bonds, to generate a double-chain ribbon (Fig. 6) in which the spacer ligand has an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1–C7–C8–C9 of 171.9(2)°. Thus, each btap− ligand can be treated as a 3-connected linker to coordinate with three Ag(I) atoms (mode c in Scheme 1). From another view, the 1D double-chain ribbon structure can be considered as consisting of alternating 6- membered and 14-membered metallacycles. The Ag…Ag separation across the 6-membered ring is 3.643 Å and that across the 14-membered ring is 6.728 Å. The double-chain ribbons are further extended into a 3D supramolecular net through aromatic π–π stacking (centriod–centriod separation of 3.954 Å) and O–H…O hydrogen bonding involving the lattice water molecules (Fig. S5).

Powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis

The experimental PXRD patterns measured for the bulk samples of complexes 1–5 are in fair agreement with the corresponding simulated ones based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. S6), which implies the phase purity of the as-synthesized products. In order to characterize the thermal behavior of this series of metal–organic hybrids, TGA experiments were performed on the bulk samples of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA profiles shown in Fig. S7 reveal that all four compounds have similar thermal decomposition processes. The first weight losses of 7.74, 7.07, 7.59 and 5.46 % in the temperature ranges of 140–180, 130–175, 130–180 and 70–220 °C for complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, correspond to the removal of two coordinated water ligands from 1, 2 and 3 (calcd 7.58, 7.48 and 6.81 %) or the release of one lattice water molecule from 5 (calcd 5.70 %). Afterward, the second weight losses of 30.52, 29.51, 27.82 and 23.26 % from 260 to 410, 270 to 410, 230 to 390 and 230 to 300 °C for 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, are consistent with the loss of CH2CH2COO− functional groups from the anionic ligands (calcd 30.32, 29.92, 27.26 and 22.80 %). Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.

Fluorescent properties

Some metal–organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π–π* transitions. However, 20–50 nm blue shifts of the emission maxima of these complexes are observed with respect to that of the free ligand. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].

Conclusions

A series of new metal–organic hybrids derived from a flexible unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylic acid ligand was prepared and characterized. These complexes are provided with three different types of coordination architectures: 1D looped-chain topological structures of 1, 2 and 3; 3D chiral framework of 4 and 1D ribbon chain of 5. Structural analysis suggests that the diverse coordination fashions of btap− ligand are the chief factors that govern the aggregation features of these compounds. Three hybrid complexes containing the zinc family metals display ligand-based fluorescence emission in the solid state. Our ongoing studies focus on the construction of hybrid coordination frameworks with varied structures and dimensionalities via tuning the conformations of the flexible bifunctional linker.

elements.clean_text: ]>This XML was provided by Springer Naturedoi:10.1007/s11243-013-9697-531aa4ebcea41b6792ab66adebe5119a0/kaist-api1110111243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-013-9697-5969710.1007/s11243-013-9697-5ArticleHydrothermal syntheses, crystal structures and fluorescent properties of five transition metal-organic hybrids incorporating an unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylate ligandZhangZhong1aHuKun1ShiYun-jia1QinJin-man1ChenZi-lu1LiangFu-pei11grid.459584.10000000121960260Key Laboratory for the Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources (Ministry of Education of China), School of Chemistry & Chemical EngineeringGuangxi Normal University541004GuilinPeople's Republic of Chinaa+86-773-5854878+86-773-5832294zhangzhong@mailbox.gxnu.edu.cn2912013420133833273341112013812201210120132912013© Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 20132013AbstractThe hydrothermal reactions of nitrate or chloride salts of Co(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Ag(I) with an unsymmetrical benzotriazole derivative 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-propionic acid (Hbtap) afforded five new metal-organic coordination polymers with formula of [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3), [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) and {[Ag(btap)]⋅H2O}n (5), which were characterized by X-ray diffraction and spectroscopic methods. The anionic btap- ligands in these complexes assume the same anti conformation, but show different coordination behaviors toward transition metal ions. Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and reveal infinite one-dimensional (1D) looped-chain structures constructed by hexacoordinated metal centers and 2-connected btap- bridges. Complex 4 features 1D zigzag polymeric arrays, which are interlinked with each other resulting in a chiral three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework. In complex 5, the 3-connected ligands join Ag(I) atoms into a 1D ribbon motif. The photoluminescence spectra of three d10 metal complexes 2, 3 and 4 were measured at room temperature. The emission peaks of these complexes resemble that of the free ligand and can be ascribed to the intraligand π-π* transitions.KeywordsHydrothermal synthesisStructural investigationFluorescenceMetal-organic hybrid1H-1,2,3-Benzotriazole-1-propionic acidpublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count8issue-article-count16issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2013issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media Dordrechtissue-copyright-year2013article-contains-esmYesarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2013article-registration-date-month1article-registration-date-day11article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11243_2013_Article_9697.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2013issue-online-date-month3issue-online-date-day14issue-print-date-year2013issue-print-date-month3issue-print-date-day13issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryCatalysisjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseElectronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s11243-013-9697-5) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionStudies on the modular assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have provided researchers in crystal engineering and materials science with a promising tool to construct extended coordination polymers with predicted structures and functionalities [1-3]. In the recent years, a great number of hybrid coordination frameworks with novel structures have been obtained by employing the modular synthesis strategy, and many of them offer a wide range of applications such as gas storage and separation, optical and chemical sensing, magnetic materials, and so on [4-7]. Even so, more experimental research will be needed to give us detailed information about the general principles of the design and synthesis of MOFs.In fact, the judicious selection of organic connectors with appropriate flexibility, suitable arrangement of the donor groups as well as specific coordination requirements may be regarded as a key ingredient in determining the dimensionality, network topology, porosity and physical-chemical properties of the metal-organic coordination networks [8-11]. For this reason, many multidentate O-containing and N-containing bridging ligands have been used as effective building blocks in the construction of the metal-organic frameworks with desired structures and properties [12-14]. Among them, azole heterocycles have proved to be versatile synthons for developing a new type of porous material termed as metal-azolate frameworks (MAFs) [15-18]. As a further investigation, the introduction of the carboxylic acid substituents on the azole rings will afford a class of bifunctional connectors with strong coordination affinity, multiple coordination modes and variable geometric conformations. In the past few years, this sub-field has drawn much attention from many research groups, and some studies on the optical properties of the metal-organic hybrids derived from these ligands have been reported [19-24]. In this paper, grafting of the flexible propionic acid pendant arm onto a benzotriazole ring gives rise to a heterocyclic carboxylic acid derivative Hbtap as bridging ligand. The coordination capability of the ligand toward some transition metal ions was investigated systematically for the first time (Scheme 1), and four low-dimensional coordination polymers formulated as [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3) and {[Ag(btap)]⋅H2O}n (5), along with a 3D chiral framework [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) were produced. The thermal behaviors and photoluminescence emission properties of some selected complexes were explored.Experimental sectionMaterials and physical measurementsThe ligand Hbtap was prepared following a published procedure [25]. All other starting materials were purchased from Merck in analytical grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was carried out using an Elementar Vario Micro Cube elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were collected at 500 MHz on a Bruker Avance AV500 instrument, (CD3)2SO and TMS were used as solvent and internal standard, respectively. IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the 4,000-400 cm-1 spectral region. Thermogravimetric analysis was obtained using a Setaram Labsys Evo TG-DTA/DSC instrument at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The fluorescence spectra were performed on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon FL3-P-TCSPC fluorescence spectrometer in the solid state at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements (PXRD) for poly-crystalline samples of complexes 1-5 were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 V diffractometer equipped with Cu-Ka radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) over the 2θ range from 5° to 60°.Synthesis of [Co(btap)2(H2O)2]n (1)A mixture of Hbtap (0.076 g, 0.40 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.058 g, 0.20 mmol) and 12 ml distilled water was sealed in a 25-ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 120 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the mixture was slowly cooled to ambient temperature over 24 h for crystallization. The pink block crystals of 1 were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water for several times and dried in air. Yield 0.040 g (42 % based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C18H20CoN6O6: C, 45.5; H, 4.2; N, 17.7 %. Found: C, 45.2; H, 4.2; N, 17.9 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3,132 (s), 1,564 (s), 1,450 (m), 1,405 (s), 1,286 (w), 1,226 (m), 1,164 (w), 1,031 (w), 849 (w), 812 (w), 777 (m), 753 (s), 689 (s), 669 (w), 609 (w).Synthesis of [Zn(btap)2(H2O)2]n (2)Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained in a manner similar to that used for the preparation of complex 1 except using Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol) in place of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Yield 0.054 g (56 % based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C18H20N6O6Zn: C, 44.9; H, 4.2; N, 17.5 %. Found: C, 44.4; H, 4.0; N, 17.4 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3,139 (m), 2,926 (m), 1,571 (s), 1,450 (m), 1,405 (s), 1,287 (s), 1,227 (m), 1,165 (w), 1,031 (w), 849 (m), 813 (m), 777 (m), 754 (s), 689 (s), 668 (m), 609 (m).Synthesis of [Cd(btap)2(H2O)2]n (3)Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained in a manner similar to that used for the preparation of complex 1 except using Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.062 g, 0.20 mmol) in place of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Yield 0.042 g (33 % based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C9H10AgN3O3: C, 34.2; H, 3.2; N, 13.3 %. Found: C, 34.5; H, 3.4; N, 13.3 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3,429 (s), 2,973 (m), 1,582 (s), 1,453 (m), 1,404 (s), 1,270 (w), 1,219 (m), 1,163 (w), 1,052 (m), 864 (w), 771 (m), 746 (m), 693 (w), 605 (w).Crystal structure determinationThe diffraction data for complexes 1-5 were collected on an Agilent SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL program package [26]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were found in the difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with the O-H bond distances restrained to 0.85 Å, all other hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined as riding models. Details of crystal data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1-5 are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) for complexes 1-5 are summarized in Table S1. Hydrogen bond distances (Å) and angles (°) for complex 1-5 are listed in Table S2.Results and discussionSynthesis and IR spectraThe ligand Hbtap was synthesized by the Michael addition of 1,2,3-benzotriazole to acrylic acid in 1:1 molar ratio, whose 1H NMR spectrum is given in Fig. S1. Complexes 1-5 were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions, and the stoichiometry of the corresponding complexes is independent of the metal to ligand ratio employed (1:1; 1:2; 1:3). However, the yields of products from different experimental runs are quite different. As shown in Fig. S2, the IR spectra of all the complexes show characteristic νas and νs stretching bands of COO- groups in the wavenumber ranges of 1,582-1,564 cm-1 and 1,417-1,404 cm-1, respectively, accompanied by the absence of the C=O stretching band of the carboxyl group, confirming that the ligands present in these solid complexes are fully deprotonated.Description of the crystal structuresComplexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and isomorphous, which exhibit the same 1D infinite looped-chain structure. Thus, we only select complex 1 as a representative to describe their crystal structures. Complex 1 belongs to monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and the local coordination environment of the central Co(II) atom is depicted in Fig. 1. As can be seen, the Co(II) atom lies on the crystallographic inversion center, and it has an N2O4 donor set defined by two triazole N atoms (N3 and N3A) from two anionic btap- ligands, two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1A) from another two btap- ligands and two O atoms (O3 and O3A) provided by two water ligands. The cis bond angles at the central Co(II) atom fall in the range of 87.30(8)°-92.70(8)°, very close to the ideal value of 90°, which reveal that the geometry around Co(II) is slightly distorted from regular octahedral. The Co-O bond length of 2.0610(18) Å and Co-N bond length of 2.0997(18) Å are all comparable to the values found for the analogous Co(II) complexes [27, 28]. In 1, each btap- serves as a bidentate linker to connect two Co(II) atoms by using its triazole group and carboxylate substituent (mode a in Scheme 1), while one Co(II) atom is surrounded by four btap- ligands, giving rise to a 1D looped-chain composed of vertex-sharing 16-membered cyclic [Co2(btap)2] subunits (Fig. 2). Within the bimetallic ring, two symmetry-related anionic ligands bridge two metal centers in a head-to-tail fashion and each of them adopts an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1-C7-C8A-C9A being -161.7(2)°. The shortest Co…Co separation through the flexible bifunctional ligand is 8.715 Å, much longer than that observed in the Co-btae- (btae- = 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-acetate) complex [27].The neighboring 1D metal-organic hybrid chains are arranged in an antiparallel fashion along the bc plane, and the O-H…O hydrogen bond interactions between water ligands and carboxylate groups assemble these 1D chains into a 2D hydrogen bonding network (Fig. S3). Viewed from the crystallographic b axis, hydrophobic aromatic rings are evenly distributed on the two sides of the 2D layer, which can facilitate the π-π stacking between the aromatic rings from adjacent layers to extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular net (Fig. S4). The interplanar distance between parallel benzotriazole rings is 3.357 Å, and the centriod-centriod separation is 4.019 Å.If HgCl2 was used as a metal source in place of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, a neutral chiral 3D metal-organic framework 4 including the coordinated Cl- ligands was generated. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the central Hg(II) atom is located in a severely distorted six-coordinated NO4Cl geometry, surrounded by a triazole N atom (N3A) of one btap- ligand, four carboxylate O atoms (O1, O2, O1B and O2C) from another three btap- ligands and a chloride ligand. The two shortest bonds around the Hg(II) atoms are to the triazole N atom and Cl- ion with the bond lengths of 2.173(7) and 2.316(2) Å, respectively. The Hg-O bond lengths change from 2.525(7) to 2.721(7) Å. These values are expected for the bonds between the chelating-bridging carboxylate and Hg(II) atoms [29]. With its μ3 chelating-bridging carboxylate group and triazole N3 atom, each btap- ligand acts as a 4-connected organic node linked with four Hg(II) atoms (mode b in Scheme 1). At first, the flexible btap- linkers join the adjacent Hg(II) atoms into a 1D zigzag chain along the b axis. The Hg…Hg separation across btap- is 10.455 Å. The ligands within the chain assume the anti conformation, having the torsion angle N1-C7-C8-C9 close to 180°. Furthermore, the 1D zigzag chains are linked with each other through the bridging action of the carboxylate O1 and O2 atoms between Hg(II) atoms coming from different 1D chains, to yield a uninodal 4-connected 3D polymeric network with a (42.63.8) topology (Fig. 4). The π-π stacking interactions between aromatic rings of adjacent chains provide additional stabilization to the 3D architecture.Complex 5 also crystallizes in a monoclinic P2(1)/c space group, yet it shows some different structural characteristics with respect to complexes 1, 2 and 3. Two chelating carboxylate O atoms (O1B and O2B) and two triazole N atoms (N3 and N2A) from three distinct btap- ligands occupy the coordination sites around the Ag(I) atom to give a twisted tetrahedral environment, where the O-Ag-N bond angles deviate from the ideal value of 109.47° (Fig. 5). The Ag-N and Ag-O bond distances vary from 2.227(2) to 2.524(2) Å and fall into the normal range for such coordination species [23]. The anionic ligands firstly bridge Ag(I) atoms through the carboxylate groups and triazole N3 atoms into a 1D linear chain running along the a axis. After that, two neighboring antiparallel chains are paired via Ag1-N2 bonds, to generate a double-chain ribbon (Fig. 6) in which the spacer ligand has an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1-C7-C8-C9 of 171.9(2)°. Thus, each btap- ligand can be treated as a 3-connected linker to coordinate with three Ag(I) atoms (mode c in Scheme 1). From another view, the 1D double-chain ribbon structure can be considered as consisting of alternating 6- membered and 14-membered metallacycles. The Ag…Ag separation across the 6-membered ring is 3.643 Å and that across the 14-membered ring is 6.728 Å. The double-chain ribbons are further extended into a 3D supramolecular net through aromatic π-π stacking (centriod-centriod separation of 3.954 Å) and O-H…O hydrogen bonding involving the lattice water molecules (Fig. S5).Powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysisThe experimental PXRD patterns measured for the bulk samples of complexes 1-5 are in fair agreement with the corresponding simulated ones based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. S6), which implies the phase purity of the as-synthesized products. In order to characterize the thermal behavior of this series of metal-organic hybrids, TGA experiments were performed on the bulk samples of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA profiles shown in Fig. S7 reveal that all four compounds have similar thermal decomposition processes. The first weight losses of 7.74, 7.07, 7.59 and 5.46 % in the temperature ranges of 140-180, 130-175, 130-180 and 70-220 °C for complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, correspond to the removal of two coordinated water ligands from 1, 2 and 3 (calcd 7.58, 7.48 and 6.81 %) or the release of one lattice water molecule from 5 (calcd 5.70 %). Afterward, the second weight losses of 30.52, 29.51, 27.82 and 23.26 % from 260 to 410, 270 to 410, 230 to 390 and 230 to 300 °C for 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, are consistent with the loss of CH2CH2COO- functional groups from the anionic ligands (calcd 30.32, 29.92, 27.26 and 22.80 %). Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.Fluorescent propertiesSome metal-organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π-π* transitions. However, 20-50 nm blue shifts of the emission maxima of these complexes are observed with respect to that of the free ligand. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].ConclusionsA series of new metal-organic hybrids derived from a flexible unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylic acid ligand was prepared and characterized. These complexes are provided with three different types of coordination architectures: 1D looped-chain topological structures of 1, 2 and 3; 3D chiral framework of 4 and 1D ribbon chain of 5. Structural analysis suggests that the diverse coordination fashions of btap- ligand are the chief factors that govern the aggregation features of these compounds. Three hybrid complexes containing the zinc family metals display ligand-based fluorescence emission in the solid state. Our ongoing studies focus on the construction of hybrid coordination frameworks with varied structures and dimensionalities via tuning the conformations of the flexible bifunctional linker.Supporting informationThe 1H NMR spectrum of Hbtap. elements.content: The hydrothermal reactions of nitrate or chloride salts of Co(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Ag(I) with an unsymmetrical benzotriazole derivative 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-propionic acid (Hbtap) afforded five new metal–organic coordination polymers with formula of [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3), [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) and {[Ag(btap)]·H2O}n (5), which were characterized by X-ray diffraction and spectroscopic methods. The anionic btap− ligands in these complexes assume the same anti conformation, but show different coordination behaviors toward transition metal ions. Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and reveal infinite one-dimensional (1D) looped-chain structures constructed by hexacoordinated metal centers and 2-connected btap− bridges. Complex 4 features 1D zigzag polymeric arrays, which are interlinked with each other resulting in a chiral three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework. In complex 5, the 3-connected ligands join Ag(I) atoms into a 1D ribbon motif. The photoluminescence spectra of three d10 metal complexes 2, 3 and 4 were measured at room temperature. The emission peaks of these complexes resemble that of the free ligand and can be ascribed to the intraligand π–π* transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The hydrothermal reactions of nitrate or chloride salts of Co(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Ag(I) with an unsymmetrical benzotriazole derivative 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-propionic acid (Hbtap) afforded five new metal-organic coordination polymers with formula of [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3), [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) and {[Ag(btap)]⋅H2O}n (5), which were characterized by X-ray diffraction and spectroscopic methods. The anionic btap- ligands in these complexes assume the same anti conformation, but show different coordination behaviors toward transition metal ions. Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and reveal infinite one-dimensional (1D) looped-chain structures constructed by hexacoordinated metal centers and 2-connected btap- bridges. Complex 4 features 1D zigzag polymeric arrays, which are interlinked with each other resulting in a chiral three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected framework. In complex 5, the 3-connected ligands join Ag(I) atoms into a 1D ribbon motif. The photoluminescence spectra of three d10 metal complexes 2, 3 and 4 were measured at room temperature. The emission peaks of these complexes resemble that of the free ligand and can be ascribed to the intraligand π-π* transitions.

elements.content: Studies on the modular assembly of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have provided researchers in crystal engineering and materials science with a promising tool to construct extended coordination polymers with predicted structures and functionalities [1–3]. In the recent years, a great number of hybrid coordination frameworks with novel structures have been obtained by employing the modular synthesis strategy, and many of them offer a wide range of applications such as gas storage and separation, optical and chemical sensing, magnetic materials, and so on [4–7]. Even so, more experimental research will be needed to give us detailed information about the general principles of the design and synthesis of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Studies on the modular assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have provided researchers in crystal engineering and materials science with a promising tool to construct extended coordination polymers with predicted structures and functionalities [1-3]. In the recent years, a great number of hybrid coordination frameworks with novel structures have been obtained by employing the modular synthesis strategy, and many of them offer a wide range of applications such as gas storage and separation, optical and chemical sensing, magnetic materials, and so on [4-7]. Even so, more experimental research will be needed to give us detailed information about the general principles of the design and synthesis of MOFs.

elements.content: In fact, the judicious selection of organic connectors with appropriate flexibility, suitable arrangement of the donor groups as well as specific coordination requirements may be regarded as a key ingredient in determining the dimensionality, network topology, porosity and physical–chemical properties of the metal–organic coordination networks [8–11]. For this reason, many multidentate O-containing and N-containing bridging ligands have been used as effective building blocks in the construction of the metal–organic frameworks with desired structures and properties [12–14]. Among them, azole heterocycles have proved to be versatile synthons for developing a new type of porous material termed as metal-azolate frameworks (MAFs) [15–18]. As a further investigation, the introduction of the carboxylic acid substituents on the azole rings will afford a class of bifunctional connectors with strong coordination affinity, multiple coordination modes and variable geometric conformations. In the past few years, this sub-field has drawn much attention from many research groups, and some studies on the optical properties of the metal–organic hybrids derived from these ligands have been reported [19–24]. In this paper, grafting of the flexible propionic acid pendant arm onto a benzotriazole ring gives rise to a heterocyclic carboxylic acid derivative Hbtap as bridging ligand. The coordination capability of the ligand toward some transition metal ions was investigated systematically for the first time (Scheme 1), and four low-dimensional coordination polymers formulated as [M(btap)2(H2O)2]n (M = Co 1, Zn 2, Cd 3) and {[Ag(btap)]·H2O}n (5), along with a 3D chiral framework [Hg(btap)Cl]n (4) were produced. The thermal behaviors and photoluminescence emission properties of some selected complexes were explored.

elements.content: The ligand Hbtap was prepared following a published procedure [25]. All other starting materials were purchased from Merck in analytical grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was carried out using an Elementar Vario Micro Cube elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were collected at 500 MHz on a Bruker Avance AV500 instrument, (CD3)2SO and TMS were used as solvent and internal standard, respectively. IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the 4,000–400 cm−1 spectral region. Thermogravimetric analysis was obtained using a Setaram Labsys Evo TG–DTA/DSC instrument at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The fluorescence spectra were performed on a Horiba Jobin–Yvon FL3-P-TCSPC fluorescence spectrometer in the solid state at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements (PXRD) for poly-crystalline samples of complexes 1–5 were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 V diffractometer equipped with Cu–Ka radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) over the 2θ range from 5° to 60°.

Experimental section

Materials and physical measurements

The ligand Hbtap was prepared following a published procedure [25]. All other starting materials were purchased from Merck in analytical grade and used without any further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was carried out using an Elementar Vario Micro Cube elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were collected at 500 MHz on a Bruker Avance AV500 instrument, (CD3)2SO and TMS were used as solvent and internal standard, respectively. IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the 4,000-400 cm-1 spectral region. Thermogravimetric analysis was obtained using a Setaram Labsys Evo TG-DTA/DSC instrument at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The fluorescence spectra were performed on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon FL3-P-TCSPC fluorescence spectrometer in the solid state at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements (PXRD) for poly-crystalline samples of complexes 1-5 were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 V diffractometer equipped with Cu-Ka radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) over the 2θ range from 5° to 60°.

elements.content: The diffraction data for complexes 1–5 were collected on an Agilent SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL program package [26]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were found in the difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with the O–H bond distances restrained to 0.85 Å, all other hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined as riding models. Details of crystal data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1–5 are listed in Table 1. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) for complexes 1–5 are summarized in Table S1. Hydrogen bond distances (Å) and angles (°) for complex 1–5 are listed in Table S2.

The ligand Hbtap was synthesized by the Michael addition of 1,2,3-benzotriazole to acrylic acid in 1:1 molar ratio, whose 1H NMR spectrum is given in Fig. S1. Complexes 1–5 were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions, and the stoichiometry of the corresponding complexes is independent of the metal to ligand ratio employed (1:1; 1:2; 1:3). However, the yields of products from different experimental runs are quite different. As shown in Fig. S2, the IR spectra of all the complexes show characteristic νas and νs stretching bands of COO− groups in the wavenumber ranges of 1,582–1,564 cm−1 and 1,417–1,404 cm−1, respectively, accompanied by the absence of the C=O stretching band of the carboxyl group, confirming that the ligands present in these solid complexes are fully deprotonated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and IR spectra

The ligand Hbtap was synthesized by the Michael addition of 1,2,3-benzotriazole to acrylic acid in 1:1 molar ratio, whose 1H NMR spectrum is given in Fig. S1. Complexes 1-5 were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions, and the stoichiometry of the corresponding complexes is independent of the metal to ligand ratio employed (1:1; 1:2; 1:3). However, the yields of products from different experimental runs are quite different. As shown in Fig. S2, the IR spectra of all the complexes show characteristic νas and νs stretching bands of COO- groups in the wavenumber ranges of 1,582-1,564 cm-1 and 1,417-1,404 cm-1, respectively, accompanied by the absence of the C=O stretching band of the carboxyl group, confirming that the ligands present in these solid complexes are fully deprotonated.

elements.content: Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and isomorphous, which exhibit the same 1D infinite looped-chain structure. Thus, we only select complex 1 as a representative to describe their crystal structures. Complex 1 belongs to monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and the local coordination environment of the central Co(II) atom is depicted in Fig. 1. As can be seen, the Co(II) atom lies on the crystallographic inversion center, and it has an N2O4 donor set defined by two triazole N atoms (N3 and N3A) from two anionic btap− ligands, two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1A) from another two btap− ligands and two O atoms (O3 and O3A) provided by two water ligands. The cis bond angles at the central Co(II) atom fall in the range of 87.30(8)°–92.70(8)°, very close to the ideal value of 90°, which reveal that the geometry around Co(II) is slightly distorted from regular octahedral. The Co–O bond length of 2.0610(18) Å and Co–N bond length of 2.0997(18) Å are all comparable to the values found for the analogous Co(II) complexes [27, 28]. In 1, each btap− serves as a bidentate linker to connect two Co(II) atoms by using its triazole group and carboxylate substituent (mode a in Scheme 1), while one Co(II) atom is surrounded by four btap− ligands, giving rise to a 1D looped-chain composed of vertex-sharing 16-membered cyclic [Co2(btap)2] subunits (Fig. 2). Within the bimetallic ring, two symmetry-related anionic ligands bridge two metal centers in a head-to-tail fashion and each of them adopts an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1–C7–C8A–C9A being −161.7(2)°. The shortest Co…Co separation through the flexible bifunctional ligand is 8.715 Å, much longer than that observed in the Co–btae− (btae− = 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-acetate) complex [27].
elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures

Complexes 1, 2 and 3 are isostructural and isomorphous, which exhibit the same 1D infinite looped-chain structure. Thus, we only select complex 1 as a representative to describe their crystal structures. Complex 1 belongs to monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and the local coordination environment of the central Co(II) atom is depicted in Fig. 1. As can be seen, the Co(II) atom lies on the crystallographic inversion center, and it has an N2O4 donor set defined by two triazole N atoms (N3 and N3A) from two anionic btap- ligands, two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1A) from another two btap- ligands and two O atoms (O3 and O3A) provided by two water ligands. The cis bond angles at the central Co(II) atom fall in the range of 87.30(8)°-92.70(8)°, very close to the ideal value of 90°, which reveal that the geometry around Co(II) is slightly distorted from regular octahedral. The Co-O bond length of 2.0610(18) Å and Co-N bond length of 2.0997(18) Å are all comparable to the values found for the analogous Co(II) complexes [27, 28]. In 1, each btap- serves as a bidentate linker to connect two Co(II) atoms by using its triazole group and carboxylate substituent (mode a in Scheme 1), while one Co(II) atom is surrounded by four btap- ligands, giving rise to a 1D looped-chain composed of vertex-sharing 16-membered cyclic [Co2(btap)2] subunits (Fig. 2). Within the bimetallic ring, two symmetry-related anionic ligands bridge two metal centers in a head-to-tail fashion and each of them adopts an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1-C7-C8A-C9A being -161.7(2)°. The shortest Co…Co separation through the flexible bifunctional ligand is 8.715 Å, much longer than that observed in the Co-btae- (btae- = 1H-1,2,3-benzotriazole-1-acetate) complex [27].

elements.content: The neighboring 1D metal–organic hybrid chains are arranged in an antiparallel fashion along the bc plane, and the O–H…O hydrogen bond interactions between water ligands and carboxylate groups assemble these 1D chains into a 2D hydrogen bonding network (Fig. S3). Viewed from the crystallographic b axis, hydrophobic aromatic rings are evenly distributed on the two sides of the 2D layer, which can facilitate the π–π stacking between the aromatic rings from adjacent layers to extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular net (Fig. S4). The interplanar distance between parallel benzotriazole rings is 3.357 Å, and the centriod–centriod separation is 4.019 Å.

elements.content: If HgCl2 was used as a metal source in place of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, a neutral chiral 3D metal–organic framework 4 including the coordinated Cl− ligands was generated. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the central Hg(II) atom is located in a severely distorted six-coordinated NO4Cl geometry, surrounded by a triazole N atom (N3A) of one btap− ligand, four carboxylate O atoms (O1, O2, O1B and O2C) from another three btap− ligands and a chloride ligand. The two shortest bonds around the Hg(II) atoms are to the triazole N atom and Cl− ion with the bond lengths of 2.173(7) and 2.316(2) Å, respectively. The Hg–O bond lengths change from 2.525(7) to 2.721(7) Å. These values are expected for the bonds between the chelating-bridging carboxylate and Hg(II) atoms [29]. With its μ3 chelating-bridging carboxylate group and triazole N3 atom, each btap− ligand acts as a 4-connected organic node linked with four Hg(II) atoms (mode b in Scheme 1). At first, the flexible btap− linkers join the adjacent Hg(II) atoms into a 1D zigzag chain along the b axis. The Hg…Hg separation across btap− is 10.455 Å. The ligands within the chain assume the anti conformation, having the torsion angle N1–C7–C8–C9 close to 180°. Furthermore, the 1D zigzag chains are linked with each other through the bridging action of the carboxylate O1 and O2 atoms between Hg(II) atoms coming from different 1D chains, to yield a uninodal 4-connected 3D polymeric network with a (42.63.8) topology (Fig. 4). The π–π stacking interactions between aromatic rings of adjacent chains provide additional stabilization to the 3D architecture.

elements.content: Complex 5 also crystallizes in a monoclinic P2(1)/c space group, yet it shows some different structural characteristics with respect to complexes 1, 2 and 3. Two chelating carboxylate O atoms (O1B and O2B) and two triazole N atoms (N3 and N2A) from three distinct btap− ligands occupy the coordination sites around the Ag(I) atom to give a twisted tetrahedral environment, where the O–Ag–N bond angles deviate from the ideal value of 109.47° (Fig. 5). The Ag–N and Ag–O bond distances vary from 2.227(2) to 2.524(2) Å and fall into the normal range for such coordination species [23]. The anionic ligands firstly bridge Ag(I) atoms through the carboxylate groups and triazole N3 atoms into a 1D linear chain running along the a axis. After that, two neighboring antiparallel chains are paired via Ag1–N2 bonds, to generate a double-chain ribbon (Fig. 6) in which the spacer ligand has an anti conformation with the torsion angle N1–C7–C8–C9 of 171.9(2)°. Thus, each btap− ligand can be treated as a 3-connected linker to coordinate with three Ag(I) atoms (mode c in Scheme 1). From another view, the 1D double-chain ribbon structure can be considered as consisting of alternating 6- membered and 14-membered metallacycles. The Ag…Ag separation across the 6-membered ring is 3.643 Å and that across the 14-membered ring is 6.728 Å. The double-chain ribbons are further extended into a 3D supramolecular net through aromatic π–π stacking (centriod–centriod separation of 3.954 Å) and O–H…O hydrogen bonding involving the lattice water molecules (Fig. S5).

elements.content: The experimental PXRD patterns measured for the bulk samples of complexes 1–5 are in fair agreement with the corresponding simulated ones based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. S6), which implies the phase purity of the as-synthesized products. In order to characterize the thermal behavior of this series of metal–organic hybrids, TGA experiments were performed on the bulk samples of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA profiles shown in Fig. S7 reveal that all four compounds have similar thermal decomposition processes. The first weight losses of 7.74, 7.07, 7.59 and 5.46 % in the temperature ranges of 140–180, 130–175, 130–180 and 70–220 °C for complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, correspond to the removal of two coordinated water ligands from 1, 2 and 3 (calcd 7.58, 7.48 and 6.81 %) or the release of one lattice water molecule from 5 (calcd 5.70 %). Afterward, the second weight losses of 30.52, 29.51, 27.82 and 23.26 % from 260 to 410, 270 to 410, 230 to 390 and 230 to 300 °C for 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, are consistent with the loss of CH2CH2COO− functional groups from the anionic ligands (calcd 30.32, 29.92, 27.26 and 22.80 %). Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis

The experimental PXRD patterns measured for the bulk samples of complexes 1-5 are in fair agreement with the corresponding simulated ones based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. S6), which implies the phase purity of the as-synthesized products. In order to characterize the thermal behavior of this series of metal-organic hybrids, TGA experiments were performed on the bulk samples of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA profiles shown in Fig. S7 reveal that all four compounds have similar thermal decomposition processes. The first weight losses of 7.74, 7.07, 7.59 and 5.46 % in the temperature ranges of 140-180, 130-175, 130-180 and 70-220 °C for complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, correspond to the removal of two coordinated water ligands from 1, 2 and 3 (calcd 7.58, 7.48 and 6.81 %) or the release of one lattice water molecule from 5 (calcd 5.70 %). Afterward, the second weight losses of 30.52, 29.51, 27.82 and 23.26 % from 260 to 410, 270 to 410, 230 to 390 and 230 to 300 °C for 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, are consistent with the loss of CH2CH2COO- functional groups from the anionic ligands (calcd 30.32, 29.92, 27.26 and 22.80 %). Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.

elements.content: Some metal–organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π–π* transitions. However, 20–50 nm blue shifts of the emission maxima of these complexes are observed with respect to that of the free ligand. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].

Fluorescent properties

Some metal-organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π-π* transitions. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].

elements.content: A series of new metal–organic hybrids derived from a flexible unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylic acid ligand was prepared and characterized. These complexes are provided with three different types of coordination architectures: 1D looped-chain topological structures of 1, 2 and 3; 3D chiral framework of 4 and 1D ribbon chain of 5. Structural analysis suggests that the diverse coordination fashions of btap− ligand are the chief factors that govern the aggregation features of these compounds. Three hybrid complexes containing the zinc family metals display ligand-based fluorescence emission in the solid state. Our ongoing studies focus on the construction of hybrid coordination frameworks with varied structures and dimensionalities via tuning the conformations of the flexible bifunctional linker.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of new metal-organic hybrids derived from a flexible unsymmetrical benzotriazole carboxylic acid ligand was prepared and characterized. These complexes are provided with three different types of coordination architectures: 1D looped-chain topological structures of 1, 2 and 3; 3D chiral framework of 4 and 1D ribbon chain of 5. Structural analysis suggests that the diverse coordination fashions of btap- ligand are the chief factors that govern the aggregation features of these compounds. Three hybrid complexes containing the zinc family metals display ligand-based fluorescence emission in the solid state. Our ongoing studies focus on the construction of hybrid coordination frameworks with varied structures and dimensionalities via tuning the conformations of the flexible bifunctional linker.

A mixture of Hbtap (0.076 g, 0.40 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.058 g, 0.20 mmol) and 12 ml distilled water was sealed in a 25-ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 120 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the mixture was slowly cooled to ambient temperature over 24 h for crystallization. The pink block crystals of 1 were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water for several times and dried in air. Yield 0.040 g (42 % based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C18H20CoN6O6: C, 45.5; H, 4.2; N, 17.7 %. Found: C, 45.2; H, 4.2; N, 17.9 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,132 (s), 1,564 (s), 1,450 (m), 1,405 (s), 1,286 (w), 1,226 (m), 1,164 (w), 1,031 (w), 849 (w), 812 (w), 777 (m), 753 (s), 689 (s), 669 (w), 609 (w).

Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained in a manner similar to that used for the preparation of complex 1 except using Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol) in place of Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Yield 0.054 g (56 % based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C18H20N6O6Zn: C, 44.9; H, 4.2; N, 17.5 %. Found: C, 44.4; H, 4.0; N, 17.4 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,139 (m), 2,926 (m), 1,571 (s), 1,450 (m), 1,405 (s), 1,287 (s), 1,227 (m), 1,165 (w), 1,031 (w), 849 (m), 813 (m), 777 (m), 754 (s), 689 (s), 668 (m), 609 (m).

Yield 0.064 g (75 % based on Hg). Anal. Calcd for C9H8ClHgN3O2: C, 25.4; H, 1.9; N, 9.9 %. Found: C, 25.8; H, 1.5; N, 9.8 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,584 (m), 3,527 (m), 3,065(w), 2,967 (w), 1,575 (s), 1,445 (m), 1,417 (s), 1,396 (s), 1,306 (m), 1,273 (m), 1,215 (m), 1,165 (m), 1,121 (w), 1,029 (w), 944 (w), 869 (m), 778 (m), 743 (s), 691 (m), 629 (w), 603 (w).

The experimental PXRD patterns measured for the bulk samples of complexes 1–5 are in fair agreement with the corresponding simulated ones based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Fig. S6), which implies the phase purity of the as-synthesized products. In order to characterize the thermal behavior of this series of metal–organic hybrids, TGA experiments were performed on the bulk samples of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA profiles shown in Fig. S7 reveal that all four compounds have similar thermal decomposition processes. The first weight losses of 7.74, 7.07, 7.59 and 5.46 % in the temperature ranges of 140–180, 130–175, 130–180 and 70–220 °C for complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, correspond to the removal of two coordinated water ligands from 1, 2 and 3 (calcd 7.58, 7.48 and 6.81 %) or the release of one lattice water molecule from 5 (calcd 5.70 %). Afterward, the second weight losses of 30.52, 29.51, 27.82 and 23.26 % from 260 to 410, 270 to 410, 230 to 390 and 230 to 300 °C for 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, are consistent with the loss of CH2CH2COO− functional groups from the anionic ligands (calcd 30.32, 29.92, 27.26 and 22.80 %). Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.

Fluorescent properties

Some metal–organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π–π* transitions. However, 20–50 nm blue shifts of the emission maxima of these complexes are observed with respect to that of the free ligand. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].

Eventually, a further increase in temperature causes the combustion of the remaining azole components for all compounds.

Fluorescent properties

Some metal-organic hybrids containing d10 metal centers reveal attractive fluorescent properties, which make them eligible candidates for chemical sensors or optical devices [30, 31]. Here, the solid state photoluminescent properties of complexes 2, 3 and 4 with d10 metal cations were investigated at ambient temperature (Fig. 7). Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of complexes 2, 3 and 4 at 323, 322 and 319 nm produces intense luminescence bands with maxima at 390, 368 and 363 nm, respectively. To interpret the nature of these emission peaks, we also have measured the fluorescent properties of the free ligand under the same conditions, and it displays a strong emission peak at 410 nm upon excitation at 327 nm. By comparing the emission spectra of the three complexes with that of Hbtap, it can be proposed that the fluorescence emission of the complexes is assigned to the intraligand π-π* transitions. However, 20-50 nm blue shifts of the emission maxima of these complexes are observed with respect to that of the free ligand. The blue shifts of the emission spectra may be induced by a number of factors, including the deprotonation of the ligand and the coordination interactions between the ligand and the metal centers [32].
